In the past, the Supreme Court has ruled that having defendants wear prison clothing when they appear before a jury impermissibly prejudices the defendant's right to a fair trial.

This term, the court accepted a case for review that could have answered that question, but it was a state case involving intervention by the lower federal courts.

The case involved a California murder.
The defendant, Matthew Musladin, claimed he was acting in self-defense when he killed his estranged wife's boyfriend.
At trial, the victim's family wore buttons that bore a picture of the dead man taken when he was in the military and wearing a uniform.
The defense claimed that was an appeal for sympathy and was misleading since the victim no longer was in the military and had drugs in his blood when he died.
Musladin was convicted and sentenced to 32 years to life in prison.
A conviction upheld by the state courts.

Supreme Court unanimously reinstated the conviction ruling as it has before that under a federal law enacted in 1996, federal courts may not order a new trial in a case where the state courts have not violated the explicit decisions of the U.S.
